Assess your lifestyle:
Evaluate your daily routine, work schedule, and living situation to ensure they align with a dog"'"s needs.
Consider your financial commitment:
Dogs require ongoing expenses like food, grooming, vet visits, and emergency care.
Research dog breeds:
Choose a breed or mix that fits your activity level, living space, and experience with pets.
Time commitment:
Dogs need daily exercise, training, and socialization. Ensure you can dedicate time to meet their needs.
Pet-friendly home:
Make sure your home is safe and accommodating for a dog, including secure fencing and off-limit areas.
Plan for training:
All dogs need basic training and socialization. Be prepared to invest time and effort.
Understand health needs:
Learn about routine care, vaccinations, parasite prevention, and grooming for dogs.
Emergency readiness:
Be prepared for unexpected medical costs or situations where your dog may need urgent care.
Consider long-term commitment:
Dogs can live 10â€“15 years or more. Ensure you"'"re ready for a long-term relationship.
Adoption vs. purchase:
Research the pros and cons of adopting from a shelter versus purchasing from a breeder.
Positive Socialization:
Provide plenty of positive socialization, especially during the puppy"'"s stage.
Regular Exercise:
Ensure your dog gets daily exercise to maintain physical health and mental stimulation.
Use Positive Reinforcement:
Reward good behavior with treats, praise, and affection to encourage positive habits.
Provide Mental Stimulation:
Engage your dog with toys, puzzles, and games to keep their mind active and prevent boredom.
Stick to a Routine:
Maintain a consistent feeding, walking, and bedtime schedule to create a sense of security.
Avoid Punishment:
Do not yell at or physically punish your dog; it can lead to fear and aggression.
Don"'"t Overfeed:
Overfeeding can lead to obesity and health issues. Stick to portion sizes recommended by your vet.
Avoid Neglecting Training:
Skipping regular training sessions can lead to behavioral problems over time.
Don"'"t Ignore Health Signs:
Always address unusual behavior, appetite changes, or symptoms of illness promptly with your vet.
Leaving Them Alone Too Long:
Dogs are social animals and can develop anxiety or destructive behaviors if left alone for extended periods.

Before Trainig

Gather essential items: collar, ID tag, leash, crate, food, bedding, and toys. 
Prepare a safe space where the dog will live, ensuring it"'"s secure, free from hazards, and away from valuable items. 
Set aside time to meet your dog"'"s basic needs, including exercise, sleep, and mental stimulation. 
Establish regular routines and rituals like morning cuddles or evening walks to build trust and consistency.
Building a Relationship

Focus on trust-building activities, such as gentle play and rewarding good behavior. 
Use positive reinforcement techniques to encourage desired actions. 
Spend quality time with your dog daily to strengthen your bond. 
Maintain eye contact and a calm, reassuring tone during interactions. 
Hand feed your dog.
Socialization

Make sure he can be calm around dogs,(start to walk where your dog can see from far away) without interact with other dogs, before actually playing with dogs 
Learn how to properly introduce dogs to each other. (in neutral ground, walking along with 2 humans in the middle of the walk.) 
Introduce your dog to various environments, people, and other animals in a controlled manner. 
Reward calm behavior and gradually increase exposure to new experiences. 
Monitor for signs of stress, and provide reassurance when needed. 
Monitor any interaction, so you can break any possible fight before it happens, and break it, as soon as possible, and try to stay calm while and after you do it.
Boundaries

Clearly define boundaries and house rules from the start. (example, not allowed in bed, or can"'t" jump on people) 
Be consistent with commands and enforce rules calmly but firmly. 
Use simple, clear language for commands to avoid confusion. 
Reward compliance with treats, praise or playtime. 
Do not inflict fear or pain, that will only ruin the relationship.
Teaching Tricks

Never start with simple tricks like "sit" 
Recall and stay are the most important lessons to teach. (Prioritize this before anything else) 
Change commands and words like, yes, no, stay, come to another language. 
Always use the same words or sound for teaching. Same tone, same volume, same energy. 
Teach to stay calm in a create 
Do not let your dog in a create for many hours. 
The trick for teaching any command is lure them into the action o position, and when done, praising with words, affection and food. 
Use a clicker or verbal cue to mark correct behaviors. 
Practice regularly in short sessions to maintain your dog"'"s focus. 
Keep training fun and engaging by incorporating play and rewards.
